10.24.text: So poultry are a naturally active and inquisitive animal

13.36.text: so a healthy, a healthy chook should be very active,

16.68.text: and should be very aware of its surrounds,

18.69.text: you and the other chooks and it

22.32.text: So if we start with the head of a healthy chook,

24.82.text: in the majority of breeds, the healthy chook has

27.51.text: a bright red comb, face and wattles.

30.99.text: Fowl pox lesions would cause abnormalities on the head,

34.12.text: face and wattles of the chook and these present as raised,

39.45.text: brown to black lesions and indicate infection with the fowl pox

43.78.text: which can be spread by mosquitoes.

46.91.text: Moving down the chook, feathers of fowls or chooks

50.21.text: should be tight, and shiny and free from

56.15.text: So the healthy chook is a complete chook.

59.82.text: It’s feathered all over and presents shiny.

63.28.text: Absence of feathers or broken feathers anywhere on the body

66.65.text: can indicate the presence of feather pecking in

69.23.text: that flock of chooks and problems that cause feather pecking

78.70.text: The legs of poultry are naturally scaled and the bone is round,

83.30.text: so the healthy chook should have a

85.28.text: closely scaled, round leg that is shiny.

88.57.text: The most common problem we see with the scales of poultry

91.39.text: is when they get infected with the scaly leg mite

93.69.text: and what that does is cause a roughness to the scale,

96.73.text: so it loses that smooth round appearance

102.83.text: So a healthy bird, when you are handling it should have

105.21.text: round muscles on the breast, and the keel bone,

109.55.text: which is the sternum of the chook, should not be sharp

112.72.text: to the hand when holding the bird.

115.10.text: That indicates good muscling of the fowl and indicates

118.39.text: adequate nutrition, general health and freedom from disease.

122.91.text: The beak on a healthy chook, the top beak should

126.65.text: sit smoothly over the bottom beak.

130.00.text: If the top beak overgrows the bottom beak too far,

133.84.text: sometimes it needs to be trimmed.

136.10.text: When we talk about external parasites of poultry,

139.66.text: the most common would be lice and mites.

142.61.text: The lice and the mites are spread by the access

145.58.text: of the poultry to wild birds so that’s

147.93.text: an important consideration in shed design.

150.76.text: So lice is commonly seen as a small, brown and

154.48.text: rapidly moving creature, most commonly seen on the vent

158.63.text: of the fowl and you’ll also see clumps of white eggs

162.78.text: that the lice leave on the poultry.

165.72.text: So the lice live on, on the fowls 100% of the time

169.86.text: and they feed on blood and skin from the fowl.

173.28.text: The poultry will lose condition from irritation

176.60.text: from infestation with lice, so when we’re considering

180.63.text: the control of lice firstly if we can restrict the access

184.34.text: of the birds or the poultry to wild birds that’s going

186.97.text: to remove a great deal of the lice from the environment.

190.45.text: However, the application of insecticides, whether that be

193.22.text: in a spray or in a dust formulation to the poultry

197.09.text: and to their shedding will reduce the incidence of the lice.

201.21.text: Red mite are different from lice because they

203.26.text: do not live on the poultry 100% of the time.

206.18.text: They actually reside in the shed.

208.71.text: They like to live in cracks in wood and we particularly

211.68.text: find that they live in cracks in the wood

216.39.text: What they do is they leave their environment

219.36.text: at night time and feed on the poultry.

222.76.text: This causes intense irritation to the fowls but what

225.90.text: it does also causes a great deal of blood loss and anaemia

230.29.text: and we can actually have deaths in poultry

233.17.text: from blood loss from red mite.

236.12.text: The most common sign you will see is paleness to the head

239.75.text: from red mite infestation and if you pick the birds up

242.68.text: you will actually find scars around the vent of the fowl

245.81.text: which is where the red mites feed.

248.73.text: Red mite, again, are transmitted by wild birds

252.12.text: so we’ve got to consider our shed design or range design

255.73.text: when we’re considering how birds are becoming infected

260.15.text: or infested with the red mite and thus how we control it.

263.35.text: Insecticides are very effective against red mite and

267.17.text: should be applied to both the birds,

271.88.text: So we need to ensure that we spray all wooden surfaces,

276.46.text: litter and nest boxes in the shed to kill the red mite.

281.19.text: Northern mite differ to red mite because they, like lice,

285.04.text: spend most of their life on the fowl.

287.42.text: The northern mite, similar to red mite cause severe anaemia

290.89.text: in the fowl but also severe irritation.

294.39.text: They’re controlled similarly to red mite by the application

297.15.text: of insecticides to the poultry but also

302.32.text: The easiest way in a school situation to do this

304.82.text: is to actually get a liquid insecticide, make this up into a

308.64.text: garden pump pack sprayer and this allows the sheds

312.44.text: and the birds to be sprayed at once.

315.98.text: I think it’s more effective and it's simpler.
